text.p: Italian luxury goods firm Gucci Group NV posted record annual profits Thursday and said it was set for its next growth phase.
Net income for fiscal 1996 more than doubled to $168.4 million from $82.9 million in fiscal 1995.
Gucci, listed on stock exchanges in New York and Amsterdam, said the results were buoyd by record performances across the board, in distribution, product categories and geographic regions.
The company designs, makes and distributes luxury accessories, including leather goods, shoes, watches, jewellery and perfume.
Revenues for fiscal 1996 increased 76.1 percent to $880.7 million versus a previous $500.1 million.
Sales for directly-operated stores rose by over 60 percent, while wholesale, including franchise, duty free and department & speciality stores, soared by over 180 percent.
Operating profit almost doubled to $239.1 million versus $121.1 million in fiscal 1995 and, as a percentage of revenues, improved to 27.2 percent from 24.2 percent in 1995.
Net income per share rose to $2.76 from $1.68.
Gross margins for the year slipped to 64.5 percent from 65.9 percent in 1995.

Second half revenues rose by 67 percent to $490.7 million compared with a previous $293.9 million, while operating profit rose to $134.5 million versus $78.6 million and, as a percentage of sales, improved to 27.4 percent from 26.7 percent.
Net income jumped to $98.4 million, or $1.61 per share, in the second half, from $56.5 million, or $1.10 per share, in the second half of fiscal 1995.

This year Gucci plans to expand and refurbish its flagship stores in London's Sloane Street and in Beverly Hills, giving them a "cleaner, more modern look which is consistent with the image of our brand," the company said.
Gucci stock was up $1.875 to $72.75 in morning trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
